title: Claude Code Integration Tools Assessment
description: Assessment covering MCP (Model Context Protocol) integration, Tool Search optimization, and git worktree workflows for parallel Claude Code sessions.

questions.questionText: What is MCP (Model Context Protocol) in Claude Code?
options: A compression algorithm for context windows
A protocol for connecting external tools and data sources to Claude
A security mechanism for permission management
A caching layer for faster responses
questions.correctAnswer: A protocol for connecting external tools and data sources to Claude
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: MCP extends Claude Code beyond its built-in tools. Database connectors, API integrations, custom search engines - MCP servers provide these capabilities through a standardized protocol. This is how you make Claude Code domain-specific: connect it to your internal tools, your company's APIs, your specialized data sources. It transforms Claude from a general assistant into a specialized team member.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a protocol for connecting external tools and data sources to Claude, extending its capabilities beyond built-in tools.

questions.questionText: What is Tool Search in Claude Code and why is it valuable?
options: A way to find files by name
A feature that reduces token usage by lazy-loading tool descriptions only when needed
A search engine for finding community tools
A debugging tool for inspecting tool calls
questions.correctAnswer: A feature that reduces token usage by lazy-loading tool descriptions only when needed
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: Every tool description consumes context tokens. With many MCP servers, you could spend 40%+ of your context just describing available tools. Tool Search solves this by loading tool descriptions on-demand - Claude sees a tool index initially, then fetches full descriptions only for tools it might use. This optimization enables large tool libraries without context bloat.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Tool Search provides significant token reduction by lazy-loading tool descriptions only when Claude determines they may be relevant to the current task.

questions.questionText: What security consideration is important when configuring MCP servers?
options: MCP servers run in a sandbox and cannot access the network
MCP servers have full system access - only use trusted servers
MCP servers are automatically audited by Anthropic
MCP servers can only read data, not write
questions.correctAnswer: MCP servers have full system access - only use trusted servers
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: MCP servers execute code on your machine with your permissions. A malicious or buggy server could read your files, make network requests, or modify data. Only install MCP servers from trusted sources, audit their code if possible, and understand what permissions they need. The power of MCP comes with responsibility for vetting what you connect.

correctAnswer.quotedText: MCP servers run with your user permissions. Only install MCP servers from trusted sources and review their capabilities before enabling.

questions.questionText: What are git worktrees and why are they useful with Claude Code?
options: A visualization of git history
Multiple working directories from one repo, enabling parallel Claude sessions on different branches
A backup mechanism for git repositories
A way to merge branches faster
questions.correctAnswer: Multiple working directories from one repo, enabling parallel Claude sessions on different branches
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: Worktrees let you have multiple checked-out copies of your repo, each on a different branch. Run one Claude session exploring a refactor in worktree A while another implements a feature in worktree B. No context switching, no stashing, no branch conflicts. This is the power-user pattern for parallel exploration - multiple Claudes, multiple branches, all progressing simultaneously.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Git worktrees enable parallel Claude Code sessions by providing separate working directories for different branches of the same repository.

questions.questionText: How does CLAUDE.md work across git worktrees?
options: Each worktree needs its own CLAUDE.md
CLAUDE.md is shared because it's in the repo - changes in one worktree appear in others after commit
CLAUDE.md is ignored in worktrees
Worktrees use the global ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md only
questions.correctAnswer: CLAUDE.md is shared because it's in the repo - changes in one worktree appear in others after commit
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: CLAUDE.md is version-controlled, so it travels with your code. When you improve CLAUDE.md in one worktree and commit, other worktrees get the update when they pull. This creates a shared 'team memory' that evolves with your project. Pro tip: designate one branch as the CLAUDE.md improvement branch and periodically merge those insights to all feature branches.

correctAnswer.quotedText: CLAUDE.md is version-controlled with your code, so improvements made in one branch propagate to others through normal git workflows.

questions.questionText: What is the recommended workflow for parallel Claude sessions using worktrees?
options: Run all sessions in the same directory with different terminals
Create worktrees for independent tasks, run separate Claude sessions in each
Use a single Claude session and rapidly switch branches
Parallel sessions are not recommended
questions.correctAnswer: Create worktrees for independent tasks, run separate Claude sessions in each
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: This workflow maximizes parallelism while maintaining isolation. Each worktree has its own file state, so Claude sessions don't interfere with each other. You can have Claude exploring architecture options in one worktree while implementing a known feature in another. The key is 'independent tasks' - parallel work that doesn't need to coordinate minute-by-minute.

correctAnswer.quotedText: For parallel development, create worktrees for independent tasks and run separate Claude Code sessions in each, allowing simultaneous progress without interference.

questions.questionText: What are the three MCP server configuration scopes in Claude Code, and what is their precedence order?
options: Global > User > Project (global settings override all)
Local > Project > User (local settings have highest priority)
User > Project > Local (user settings always win)
Project > Local > User (team settings override personal)
questions.correctAnswer: Local > Project > User (local settings have highest priority)
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: Understanding scope precedence prevents the #1 MCP configuration error - 'server not found'. Local scope (personal, current project) overrides Project scope (team-shared .mcp.json), which overrides User scope (cross-project personal). This lets you override team configurations when needed while maintaining shared defaults.

correctAnswer.quotedText: MCP configuration scopes: Local > Project > User. Local settings have highest priority and override project and user settings.

questions.questionText: What specific security risk does Anthropic warn about when using MCP servers that fetch untrusted content?
options: Slower response times due to network latency
Higher API costs from additional token usage
Exposure to prompt injection attacks
Memory leaks from poorly written servers
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: MCP servers that fetch content from external sources (web scrapers, email readers, issue trackers) can inadvertently inject malicious prompts into Claude's context. An attacker could embed hidden instructions in a GitHub issue or email that manipulates Claude's behavior. This is why Anthropic specifically warns: 'Be especially careful when using MCP servers that could fetch untrusted content.'

correctAnswer.quotedText: Be especially careful when using MCP servers that could fetch untrusted content, as these can expose you to prompt injection risk.

questions.questionText: When does Claude Code's MCP Tool Search automatically activate?
options: Always enabled when any MCP server is connected
When MCP tool descriptions would exceed 10% of the context window
Only when manually enabled with /tool-search command
When using more than 5 MCP servers simultaneously
questions.correctAnswer: When MCP tool descriptions would exceed 10% of the context window
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: Tool Search runs in 'auto' mode by default - it activates only when your MCP tool definitions would consume more than 10% of context. This prevents context bloat while maintaining access to all tools. With many servers, tool definitions can consume 40%+ of context before you even start. Tool Search reduced Anthropic's internal tool definitions from 134K tokens to on-demand lookups.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Tool Search activates in auto mode when tool descriptions would exceed 10% of context window. Configurable threshold with auto:N syntax.

questions.questionText: How should teams share MCP server configurations across all team members?
options: Email the configuration to each team member
Create a .mcp.json file at the project root and check it into version control
Each team member must configure MCP servers individually
MCP servers cannot be shared between team members
questions.correctAnswer: Create a .mcp.json file at the project root and check it into version control
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: Project-scoped MCP configurations in .mcp.json are automatically picked up by all team members when they clone the repository. This ensures everyone has access to the same tools - database connectors, API integrations, internal services. One central configuration, distributed through normal version control.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Project-scoped MCP configurations in .mcp.json are version-controlled and automatically apply to all team members.

questions.questionText: Why was the Claude Code SDK renamed to Claude Agent SDK?
options: To indicate it's only for automated agents, not human interaction
Because the agent harness powering Claude Code is useful for many non-coding applications
To separate coding tools from general AI capabilities
Due to trademark concerns
questions.correctAnswer: Because the agent harness powering Claude Code is useful for many non-coding applications
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: The rename reflects that Claude Code's underlying agent architecture is general-purpose. Teams at Anthropic use it as a general agent, not just for code. The SDK lets you build custom agents for any domain - customer support, research, data analysis - using the same battle-tested infrastructure that powers Claude Code.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Claude Code SDK renamed to Claude Agent SDK. Claude Code is All You Need - the team uses it as a general agent, not just for code.

questions.questionText: What is a Claude Code plugin?
options: A browser extension for Claude.ai
A collection of related skills, agents, and hooks bundled together
A paid add-on from Anthropic
A security scanning tool
questions.correctAnswer: A collection of related skills, agents, and hooks bundled together
questions.explanation: WHY THIS MATTERS: Plugins bundle related capabilities for distribution. A 'deployment' plugin might include a /deploy skill, pre-deployment validation hooks, and specialized agents for infrastructure analysis. The /plugin command lets you add marketplaces and discover community-built extensions, rapidly expanding Claude's capabilities without manual configuration.

correctAnswer.quotedText: Plugins bundle related skills, agents, and hooks together for distribution via the marketplace.
